Description: Egyptioan terracotta figure of Eros. Feet, wings arms at elbow and part of head broken off and lost. Standing figure, the head is very slightly inclined, and the eyes gaze away into the distance. The left leg is bent at the knee, throwing the body into an easy attitude, and making the right hip project. Both arms were bent at the elbow (they are now missing below that joint), and a garment thrown over the left arm falls in folds by the side of the body. Soft (gypsum?) white coating covered in pink (skin), red-brown (hair) and blue (wings) paint. Robe hanging off left arm was left white. Mould-made. Nile silt orange-brown fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold and silver mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Unclear pencil writing on back. Probably locally made. Gutch dates this piece to 200BC (Hogarth 1899, 96, pl.12, no.291), and a Ptolemaic date is likely based on its stregraphical position (above Gutch's 'second group' of Classical Greek figures, Hogarth et. al. 1899, 72).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.229) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 96, no. 291, pl. XII, no. 291)
